G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000 when including property damage, consequential damages, costs, and interest, or, in the alternative, because Plaintiff elects to file in the Superior Court.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: Personal jurisdiction over Defendant is proper because Defendant is a resident of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and the acts and omissions complained of occurred within Massachusetts. See G.L. c. 223A, § 3.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 & 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Hampden Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 & 2, because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Hampden County and both Plaintiff and Defendant reside in Hampden County.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others and their property.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.support_reasoning: The court expressly articulates a general Massachusetts tort principle that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, with foreseeability as a precondition. While the case then applies this to the specific context of firearm storage, the quoted general rule squarely supports the broad proposition about a duty of reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others and their property.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.relevant_excerpt: "We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor. See Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 640, 646 (1990)..."

Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675, 677\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others and their property.
Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675, 677\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states, as a general principle of tort law, that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, citing the Restatement. Although the case ultimately carves out an exception for a pregnant woman’s duty to her fetus, its articulation of the baseline duty rule squarely supports the cited proposition about Massachusetts negligence law in general.
Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675, 677\u2.relevant_excerpt: “Whether a duty exists is a question of common law, to be determined by ‘reference to existing social values and customs and appropriate social policy.’ … As a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 302 comment a (1965) (‘In general, anyone who does an affirmative act is under a duty to others to exercise the care of a reasonable man to protect them against an unreasonable risk of harm to them arising out of the act’).”

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others and their property.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses duty in negligence generally and focuses on the specific duties of landowners and possessors of land, especially regarding adjacent public highways. It does not articulate a broad, universal Massachusetts rule that "every person" has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others and their property. Instead, it frames duty in terms of established categories (e.g., landowners, possessors, controllers of land) and policy, so it is not good authority for the sweeping, generalized proposition stated.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: Before liability for negligence can be imposed, there must first be a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, and a breach of that duty proximately resulting in the injury. See O’Gorman v. Antonio Rubinaccio & Sons, 408 Mass. 758, 760 (1990); Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp., 404 Mass. 624, 629 (1989). Whether such a duty exists is a question of law. Wallace v. Wilson, 411 Mass. 8, 12 (1991), citing Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp., supra. In determining whether the defendant had a duty to be careful, we look to existing social values and customs, as well as to appropriate social policy.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85 (comparative negl.raw_text: G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence; presupposing existence of negligence duty and breach).
G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85 (comparative negl.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others and their property.

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.proposition: A negligence claim in Massachusetts requires: (1) a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff; (2) a breach of that duty; (3) a causal connection between the breach and the injury; and (4) actual damages.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion describes the elements of negligence but does not list them in the four-part formulation given in the proposition. Instead, it states that plaintiffs must prove breach of duty, actual loss, and causation, without separately articulating "duty" as an element or using the precise four-element structure. Thus, while generally consistent with negligence principles, this case is not good authority for that specific four-element statement.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.relevant_excerpt: With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 639 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the use and storage of his personal property, including the Ladder, so as not to create an unreasonable and foreseeable risk of harm to Plaintiff and her property.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The quoted portion is a concurrence focused on causation and foreseeability, not on defining or affirming any duty regarding use and storage of personal property such as a ladder. It states only that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence, without articulating a specific duty of care in the storage/use of property. Thus, this citation does not support the specific duty proposition claimed.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

Flood v. Southland Corp., 416 Mass. 62,.proposition: Defendant also owed Plaintiff a duty not to unreasonably endanger her property in the shared driveway area that both parties regularly used and that Defendant knew Plaintiff relied upon for parking and maneuvering her vehicle.
Flood v. Southland Corp., 416 Mass. 62,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a stabbing outside a convenience store and discusses a store's duty of reasonable care to protect patrons from third-party criminal acts. It does not involve neighboring landowners, shared driveways, or any duty specifically related to not unreasonably endangering another’s property in a shared parking or maneuvering area. The duty recognized is a general premises-liability duty to protect customers from foreseeable harm, not the more specific property-based duty described in the proposition.
Flood v. Southland Corp., 416 Mass. 62,.relevant_excerpt: “Southland owed a duty of reasonable care to the plaintiff (Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707-708 [1973]) to prevent injury by third persons whether their acts were accidental, negligent, or intentional (Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 452 [1969]). Southland argues, however, that it owed no duty to the plaintiff in this case because the risk that led to the plaintiff's injury was not one which could be reasonably anticipated by the defendant.”

Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp.,.raw_text: Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp., 404 Mass. 624, 629 (1989) (duty measured by what a reasonably prudent person would anticipate as possible harm).
Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp.,.proposition: Defendant’s duty included the obligation to secure or properly store objects on or near the shared driveway, such as the Ladder, to prevent them from being blown or knocked over onto Plaintiff’s vehicle in foreseeable windy conditions.
Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp.,.support_reasoning: This decision concerns the scope of duty in the context of movie producers and theatre owners allegedly causing a third party’s violent criminal act through exhibition of a film and related conduct. It does not involve premises liability, shared driveways, or any duty to secure physical objects against foreseeable weather conditions, nor does it articulate a rule about securing items like ladders to prevent damage to neighboring property. The cited case therefore does not provide authority for the proposition about a duty to secure objects near a shared driveway in windy conditions.
Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp.,.relevant_excerpt: “‘There can be negligence only where there is a duty to be careful,’ Theriault v. Pierce, 307 Mass. 532, 533 (1940), and whether there is a duty to be careful is a question of law. Monadnock Display Fireworks, Inc. v. Andover, 388 Mass. 153, 156 (1983). In determining whether the law ought to provide that a duty of care is owed by one person to another, we look to existing social values and customs, and to appropriate social policy.”

Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.raw_text: Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978) (proximate cause satisfied where harm is within the scope of foreseeable risk).
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.proposition: The type of harm suffered by Plaintiff—physical damage to her vehicle and resulting economic losses from repairs and loss of use—was precisely the kind of harm that was reasonably foreseeable from leaving a tall, unsecured ladder leaning adjacent to a driveway in windy conditions, particularly after Plaintiff had complained of that exact risk.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.support_reasoning: The case does stand for the general proximate cause principle that liability exists where the harm is within the scope of foreseeable risk, but the specific proposition here concerns foreseeability of *property* damage to a vehicle and related economic loss from an unsecured ladder. Jesionek involves *personal injury to a pedestrian* caused by an unsecured forklift operated by an intoxicated seaman, and the court’s foreseeability analysis is framed around bodily injury to persons known to pass through the area, not damage to vehicles or economic loss. Thus, it supports the general foreseeability/proximate cause principle but not the specific, vehicle‑damage scenario claimed.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.relevant_excerpt: “Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable. … It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition on premises which were solely under the authority’s control, would be operated by unauthorized persons… It was also reasonably foreseeable… that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area, such as those visiting the ships. … Consequently, a jury could have found that the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible.”

Fenn v. Mansfield, 331 Mass. 466, 469 (1.raw_text: Fenn v. Mansfield, 331 Mass. 466, 469 (1954) (foreseeable natural forces do not break chain of causation).
Fenn v. Mansfield, 331 Mass. 466, 469 (1.proposition: The occurrence of windy conditions in March in Springfield, Massachusetts, was entirely foreseeable and ordinary, and not an extraordinary event.
Fenn v. Mansfield, 331 Mass. 466, 469 (1.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Fenn v. Mansfield concerns contractual risk allocation and the scope of a subcontractor’s obligations to repair damage, not the foreseeability of natural forces or weather conditions such as March winds in Springfield. The opinion does not discuss ordinary versus extraordinary weather events, foreseeability of wind, or causation principles related to natural forces. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition that March wind in Springfield is entirely foreseeable and ordinary.
Fenn v. Mansfield, 331 Mass. 466, 469 (1.relevant_excerpt: There is no discussion in the provided text of weather, wind, natural forces, or their foreseeability; the opinion focuses on contract specifications and the contractor’s and subcontractor’s obligations to repair damage and protect property during excavation.

Hopkins v. Medeiros, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 6.raw_text: Hopkins v. Medeiros, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 600, 603 (2000) (damages for property loss include cost of repair and loss of use);
Hopkins v. Medeiros, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 6.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including the reasonable cost of repairing her vehicle, the reasonable rental value or actual cost of a substitute vehicle during the repair period, her insurance deductible, and other consequential damages.
Hopkins v. Medeiros, 48 Mass. App. Ct. 6.support_reasoning: The opinion in Hopkins v. Medeiros concerns duty, the rescue doctrine, and the firefighter’s rule; it does not address the measure of damages for property loss or vehicle repair, rental value, deductibles, or consequential damages. There is no discussion of damages for property loss or any articulation of the rule that such damages include cost of repair and loss of use. Accordingly, this case does not support the cited damages proposition and appears to be mis-cited for that purpose.

Guaranty-First Trust Co. v. Textron, Inc.raw_text: Guaranty-First Trust Co. v. Textron, Inc., 416 Mass. 332, 336 (1993).
Guaranty-First Trust Co. v. Textron, Inc.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including the reasonable cost of repairing her vehicle, the reasonable rental value or actual cost of a substitute vehicle during the repair period, her insurance deductible, and other consequential damages.
Guaranty-First Trust Co. v. Textron, Inc.case_name: Guaranty-First Trust Co. v. Textron, Inc.
Guaranty-First Trust Co. v. Textron, Inc.support_reasoning: The case concerns the measure of damages for contamination to real property under Mass. G.L. c. 21E and, by analogy, the common‑law measure of property damage (diminution in value, cost of repair, and loss of use/rental value for the reasonable repair period). It does not address damages in an automobile negligence context, nor does it mention recovery of vehicle repair costs, rental of a substitute vehicle, insurance deductibles, or other personal-injury-type consequential damages. Thus, it does not support the broad proposition stated about a plaintiff’s entitlement to all such categories of damages in a negligence case involving a damaged vehicle.
Guaranty-First Trust Co. v. Textron, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “At common law, ‘[t]he general rule for measuring property damage is diminution in market value.’ … ‘If the injury is reasonably curable by repairs, the expense of repairs, if less than the diminished market value, is the measure of recovery.’ … A party suffering property damage may also recover for loss of use. … Lost rent is therefore an appropriate part of the remedy for damage to real property to the extent it represents diminution in market value or loss of use.”

G.L. c. 235, \u00a7 8.proposition: Plaintiff also seeks statutory post‑judgment interest on any damages awarded, pursuant to G.L. c. 235, § 8, and prejudgment interest as applicable pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B or § 6C (depending on classification of the claim as personal or property damage in tort).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B or \u00a7 6C.proposition: Plaintiff also seeks statutory post‑judgment interest on any damages awarded, pursuant to G.L. c. 235, § 8, and prejudgment interest as applicable pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B or § 6C (depending on classification of the claim as personal or property damage in tort).
